par.text: Antimony is a metalloid, exhibiting intermediate properties between metals and non-metals. It occurs in two allotropic forms: mostly in the metallic form, silvery-grey in colour. The other form is amorphous and black in colour. Antimony compounds have been known since ancient times. In the 16th century it was identified as an element by alchemists. The English name is derived from the Greek words

, meaning ”not alone”, suggesting that the element does not occur naturally in the free state. The name Stibium was given to antimony by Antoine Laurent Lavoisier in the 1780s. Antimony and its compounds are poisonous.
